metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: investigate and apply theoretically and practically Newton's three laws of motion in situations where two or more coplanar forces act along a straight line and in two dimensions

first_law_equilibrium.name: Equilibrium and Constant Velocity
first_law_equilibrium.correct: When net force is zero, an object maintains its current state: stationary objects stay still, moving objects continue at constant velocity.

acceleration.error: Zero net force means zero acceleration, not non-zero acceleration.
acceleration.fix: a = ΣF/m. If ΣF = 0, then a = 0. The object doesn't speed up or slow down.
acceleration.action: Calculate: if Fnet = 0 and m = 5 kg, what is a?

speed.error: Speed is scalar; the First Law refers to velocity, which is a vector.
speed.fix: Constant velocity means both speed AND direction remain unchanged.
speed.action: Can an object have constant speed but changing velocity? Think circular motion.

momentum.error: While momentum is conserved, the First Law specifically describes motion state.
momentum.fix: First Law: no net force → constant velocity. Momentum conservation is a separate principle.
momentum.action: The First Law is about individual objects. Momentum conservation is about systems.

rest.error: Objects don't necessarily come to rest when forces are balanced.
rest.fix: Balanced forces maintain current state. A moving object stays moving at constant velocity.
rest.action: A spaceship with engines off in deep space: does it stop or keep moving?

persistent.gap: You're not connecting zero net force to unchanged motion state.
persistent.action: Practice: for each scenario, identify if Fnet = 0. If yes, predict the motion.

inertia_definition.name: Inertia
inertia_definition.correct: Inertia is an object's resistance to changes in its motion. It depends ONLY on mass, not weight or velocity.

weight.error: Weight is a force (mg). Inertia is a property of matter.
weight.fix: Inertia depends on mass alone. Weight depends on mass AND gravitational field.
weight.action: Your inertia is the same on Earth and the Moon. Is your weight?

momentum.error: Momentum (mv) depends on velocity. Inertia depends only on mass.
momentum.fix: A stationary truck has high inertia but zero momentum. They're different concepts.
momentum.action: Does a parked car have inertia? Does it have momentum?

velocity.error: Inertia doesn't depend on how fast something is moving.
velocity.fix: Mass determines inertia. A stationary 1000 kg car has the same inertia as a moving one.
velocity.action: Why is it hard to push a stationary truck? It's not moving, so velocity isn't the factor.

force.error: Force causes change in motion. Inertia resists that change.
force.fix: More inertia (mass) means more force needed to achieve the same acceleration.
force.action: F = ma rearranged: a = F/m. More mass → less acceleration for same force.

persistent.gap: You're confusing inertia with related but different concepts.
persistent.action: Define each: inertia (resistance to Δv), weight (force), momentum (mass × velocity). Note what each depends on.

net_force_definition.name: Net Force
net_force_definition.formula: Fnet = ΣF = vector sum of all forces
net_force_definition.correct: Net force is the vector sum of ALL forces acting on an object. It determines the object's acceleration.

largest force.error: Net force is the vector SUM, not the largest individual force.
largest force.fix: Add all forces as vectors. Opposite directions can cancel or partially cancel.
largest force.action: Two forces: 10 N right, 6 N left. Net force = 4 N right, not 10 N.

applied force.error: Applied force is just one of possibly many forces on the object.
applied force.fix: Net force includes ALL forces: gravity, normal, friction, tension, applied, etc.
applied force.action: List all forces on a book sitting on a table. The net force is their sum.

mass times velocity.fix: Net force = ΣF. It causes acceleration. Momentum = mv is different.
mass times velocity.action: Check units: Force is in Newtons (kg⋅m/s²). Momentum is in kg⋅m/s.

resultant acceleration.error: Acceleration results FROM the net force; it isn't the net force itself.
resultant acceleration.fix: Net force causes acceleration: Fnet = ma → a = Fnet/m.
resultant acceleration.action: Net force has units of Newtons. Acceleration has units of m/s². Different things.

persistent.gap: You're not clear on what net force actually represents.
persistent.action: For every scenario: list all forces, add them as vectors, get net force. Then find acceleration.

second_law_formula.name: Newton's Second Law Formula
second_law_formula.correct: Fnet = ma. Net force equals mass times acceleration. This is the quantitative relationship between force and motion change.

F = mv.error: That's momentum, not Newton's Second Law.
F = mv.fix: F = ma (force = mass × acceleration). p = mv (momentum = mass × velocity).
F = mv.action: Check units: ma gives kg⋅m/s² = N. mv gives kg⋅m/s ≠ N.

F = ma².error: Acceleration is not squared in Newton's Second Law.
F = ma².fix: F = ma. No squaring of acceleration.
F = ma².action: Dimensional analysis: kg × (m/s²) = kg⋅m/s² = N. Check: kg × (m/s²)² ≠ N.

F = m/a.error: Division is wrong. Force is directly proportional to acceleration.
F = m/a.fix: F = ma means F = m × a. More acceleration requires more force.
F = m/a.action: If you double the acceleration, do you need more or less force?

a = Fm.error: Rearrangement is wrong. It should be a = F/m.
a = Fm.fix: From F = ma, rearrange: a = F/m. Acceleration equals force DIVIDED BY mass.
a = Fm.action: Rearrange algebraically: F = ma → a = F/m. Mass in denominator.

persistent.gap: You don't have the Second Law formula memorised correctly.
persistent.action: Write F = ma 10 times. Then do 5 calculations each for F, m, and a.

second_law_proportionality.name: Second Law Proportionality
second_law_proportionality.correct: Acceleration is directly proportional to net force and inversely proportional to mass. Double the force → double the acceleration. Double the mass → half the acceleration.

directly proportional to mass.error: Acceleration is INVERSELY proportional to mass.
directly proportional to mass.fix: a = F/m. m is in the denominator. More mass → less acceleration.
directly proportional to mass.action: Same force on 1 kg and 2 kg masses. Which accelerates more?

inversely proportional to force.error: Acceleration is DIRECTLY proportional to force.
inversely proportional to force.fix: a = F/m. More force → more acceleration, not less.
inversely proportional to force.action: Push a cart gently, then hard. Which produces more acceleration?

independent of mass.fix: a = F/m. Mass is in the formula. Different masses → different accelerations for same force.
independent of mass.action: Push a shopping cart vs a car with same force. Same acceleration?

independent of force.error: Acceleration definitely depends on net force.
independent of force.fix: a = F/m. No force → no acceleration. More force → more acceleration.
independent of force.action: A book at rest on a table has zero net force. What's its acceleration?

persistent.gap: You're not clear on how a, F, and m relate mathematically.
persistent.action: Make a table: keep F constant, vary m, calculate a. Then keep m constant, vary F, calculate a.

third_law_pairs.name: Action-Reaction Force Pairs
third_law_pairs.correct: Every force has an equal and opposite reaction force. These forces act on DIFFERENT objects and are the same type of force.

same object.error: Action-reaction pairs act on DIFFERENT objects.
same object.fix: If A pushes B, B pushes back on A. One force on B, one force on A.
same object.action: You push a wall. The force on the wall is from you. The reaction force is on you from the wall.

cancel out.error: They don't cancel because they act on different objects.
cancel out.fix: Forces only cancel when on the SAME object. A-R pairs are on different objects.
cancel out.action: Draw free-body diagrams for both objects separately. Each diagram has one force from the pair.

normal force and weight.error: These are NOT an action-reaction pair even though they're equal and opposite.
normal force and weight.fix: Both act on the same object (the sitting object). They're not a Newton 3 pair.
normal force and weight.action: Weight: Earth pulls object. Reaction: Object pulls Earth (not normal force).

different magnitudes.error: Action and reaction forces are ALWAYS equal in magnitude.
different magnitudes.fix: Newton's Third Law: forces are equal and opposite. No exceptions.
different magnitudes.action: A truck hits a car. Force on car = force on truck. Accelerations differ because masses differ.

persistent.gap: You're not identifying action-reaction pairs correctly.
persistent.action: Practice: for each force, name the two objects and the force type. The reaction has same type, same objects (swapped), opposite direction.

third_law_notation.name: Third Law Notation
third_law_notation.correct: Use 'force on A by B' notation. The reaction is 'force on B by A'. Same type of force, objects swapped, opposite direction.

force from A on B.error: Standard notation is 'force ON A BY B', not 'from A'.
force from A on B.fix: ON names the object experiencing the force. BY names the object exerting it.
force from A on B.action: Practice: 'force on book by table' → reaction is 'force on table by book'.

force of A and B.error: This doesn't specify which object experiences which force.
force of A and B.fix: 'Force on A by B' is clear: A feels it, B causes it.
force of A and B.action: Ambiguity leads to errors. Be precise: ON and BY.

force between A and B.error: This is vague. There are TWO forces, one on each object.
force between A and B.fix: Specify each force separately: force on A by B, and force on B by A.
force between A and B.action: Draw both objects. Label each force with ON and BY.

persistent.gap: You're not using precise notation for forces.
persistent.action: Rewrite 10 force descriptions using 'force ON [object] BY [object]' format.

free_body_diagram.name: Free Body Diagrams
free_body_diagram.formula: Show all forces on ONE object
free_body_diagram.correct: A free body diagram shows ALL forces acting on a single object. Each force arrow starts from the object and points in the direction the force acts.

multiple objects.error: A free body diagram shows forces on ONE object only.
multiple objects.fix: Isolate one object. Show only forces acting ON it, not forces it exerts.
multiple objects.action: For a system of objects, draw separate FBDs for each object.

velocity vectors.error: FBDs show forces, not velocity or acceleration.
velocity vectors.fix: Forces cause acceleration. Show the forces. Acceleration can be deduced from net force.
velocity vectors.action: Forces have units of Newtons. Velocity has units of m/s. Don't mix them.

reaction forces on other objects.error: Only show forces ON the object, not forces BY the object.
reaction forces on other objects.fix: If analysing object A, show forces on A. The force A exerts on B belongs on B's FBD.
reaction forces on other objects.action: Ask: 'What forces does this object FEEL?' not 'What forces does it EXERT?'

only applied forces.error: Must include ALL forces: gravity, normal, friction, tension, applied, etc.
only applied forces.fix: Every force on the object matters for calculating net force.
only applied forces.action: Checklist: gravity? normal? friction? tension? applied? any other contact forces?

persistent.gap: You're not constructing free body diagrams correctly.
persistent.action: Practice 10 FBDs. For each: isolate one object, list all forces ON it, draw arrows from object centre.

force_components.name: Resolving Forces into Components
force_components.formula: Fx = F cos θ, Fy = F sin θ
force_components.correct: Any force can be resolved into perpendicular components. Use trigonometry: Fx = F cos θ (horizontal), Fy = F sin θ (vertical) where θ is from horizontal.

Fx = F sin θ.error: For angle from horizontal, x-component uses cosine.
Fx = F sin θ.fix: Fx = F cos θ when θ is measured from the x-axis. Adjacent side uses cosine.
Fx = F sin θ.action: Draw a right triangle. Label sides relative to angle. Adjacent = cos, opposite = sin.

Fy = F cos θ.error: For angle from horizontal, y-component uses sine.
Fy = F cos θ.fix: Fy = F sin θ when θ is measured from the x-axis. Opposite side uses sine.

Fx = F/cos θ.fix: Components are smaller than the total force. Multiply, don't divide.
Fx = F/cos θ.action: A component can't be larger than the original force. Division would increase it.

F = Fx + Fy.fix: F = √(Fx² + Fy²). This is Pythagoras, not regular addition.
F = Fx + Fy.action: If Fx = 3 N and Fy = 4 N, F = 5 N, not 7 N.

persistent.gap: You're struggling with trigonometric resolution of forces.
persistent.action: Review SOH-CAH-TOA. Practice: draw force at angle, resolve into components, verify F² = Fx² + Fy².

inclined_plane_components.name: Forces on Inclined Planes
inclined_plane_components.formula: F∥ = mg sin θ, F⊥ = mg cos θ
inclined_plane_components.correct: On an incline at angle θ: component parallel to slope = mg sin θ (causes sliding), component perpendicular = mg cos θ (causes normal force).

F∥ = mg cos θ.error: Parallel component uses sine, not cosine.
F∥ = mg cos θ.fix: The parallel component is OPPOSITE to the angle in the triangle. Sin for opposite.
F∥ = mg cos θ.action: Draw the geometry. The angle θ of the slope equals the angle between weight and perpendicular.

F⊥ = mg sin θ.error: Perpendicular component uses cosine, not sine.
F⊥ = mg sin θ.fix: The perpendicular component is ADJACENT to the angle. Cos for adjacent.
F⊥ = mg sin θ.action: At θ = 0° (flat): perpendicular should equal mg. cos(0°) = 1. ✓

F∥ = mg tan θ.error: Tangent gives ratio of components, not the component itself.
F∥ = mg tan θ.fix: tan θ = sin θ / cos θ = F∥/F⊥. Components use sin and cos directly.
F∥ = mg tan θ.action: Check units: mg tan θ still has units of N, but it's the wrong formula.

F⊥ = mg.error: Full weight only acts perpendicular on a horizontal surface.
F⊥ = mg.fix: On an incline, F⊥ = mg cos θ. It's less than mg.
F⊥ = mg.action: At θ = 90° (vertical): F⊥ = mg cos 90° = 0. Makes sense—no normal force on a cliff.

persistent.gap: You're confusing sin and cos for inclined plane components.
persistent.action: Memory trick: 'parallel to slope = sine; perpendicular to slope = cosine'. Verify at 0° and 90°.

two_dimensional_forces.name: Forces in Two Dimensions
two_dimensional_forces.correct: Apply Newton's Second Law separately to each perpendicular direction. Sum forces in x-direction, sum forces in y-direction, then find acceleration components.

add all forces directly.error: Forces in different directions can't be added arithmetically.
add all forces directly.fix: Resolve all forces into x and y components. Sum x-components separately from y-components.
add all forces directly.action: 10 N right and 10 N up don't add to 20 N. They add to √(10² + 10²) = 14.1 N.

use largest force only.error: All forces contribute to the net force.
use largest force only.fix: Vector sum of ALL forces determines acceleration.
use largest force only.action: Three forces at different angles: resolve each, sum all x, sum all y, combine.

ignore perpendicular forces.fix: A force can cause acceleration in any direction it has a component.
ignore perpendicular forces.action: A force at 45°: affects both x and y motion.

magnitude only matters.error: Direction is crucial for vector addition.
magnitude only matters.fix: Two 10 N forces can give anywhere from 0 N to 20 N net force, depending on directions.
magnitude only matters.action: Draw 10 N + 10 N when parallel vs antiparallel vs perpendicular.

persistent.gap: You're not applying vector addition correctly in 2D.
persistent.action: Practice: resolve forces, sum components, find net force magnitude and direction. Do 10 problems.

equilibrium_conditions.name: Conditions for Equilibrium
equilibrium_conditions.correct: An object is in equilibrium when net force in EVERY direction equals zero. Both x and y components of net force must be zero.

ΣF = 0 in one direction only.error: Equilibrium requires zero net force in ALL directions.
ΣF = 0 in one direction only.fix: If ΣFx = 0 but ΣFy ≠ 0, the object accelerates in the y-direction.
ΣF = 0 in one direction only.action: Check both: is ΣFx = 0? AND is ΣFy = 0? Both must be true.

equal forces in opposite directions.error: This is necessary but not sufficient for 2D equilibrium.
equal forces in opposite directions.fix: All forces must sum to zero when resolved into x and y components.
equal forces in opposite directions.action: Three forces can balance even if no two are directly opposite.

object must be stationary.error: Equilibrium means zero acceleration, not zero velocity.
object must be stationary.fix: An object moving at constant velocity is in equilibrium (First Law).
object must be stationary.action: A car cruising at constant 60 km/h on a straight road is in equilibrium.

no forces act on object.error: Equilibrium can occur with many forces, as long as they balance.
no forces act on object.fix: Forces can be present. Their vector sum must be zero.
no forces act on object.action: A book on a table has two forces (weight and normal) but is in equilibrium.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly identifying equilibrium conditions.
persistent.action: For each scenario: resolve forces, check ΣFx = 0 AND ΣFy = 0. Both required.

first_law.title: Newton's First Law - Law of Inertia
first_law.instructions: Complete the statements about Newton's First Law and inertia.

sentences.text: Newton's First Law states that an object at rest will remain at rest, and an object in motion will continue moving with constant {{d1}}, unless acted upon by a {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Velocity includes both magnitude and direction.

d2.tooltip: What type of force changes an object's motion state?

sentences.text: The tendency of an object to resist changes in its state of motion is called {{d3}}, which depends only on the object's {{d4}}.

d4.tooltip: This is an intrinsic property, not a force.

sentences.text: When all forces on an object sum to zero, the net force equals {{d5}}, and the object experiences {{d6}} acceleration.

d5.tooltip: What is the sum of balanced forces?

second_law.title: Newton's Second Law - F = ma
second_law.instructions: Complete the statements about Newton's Second Law.

sentences.text: Newton's Second Law states that the acceleration of an object is {{d1}} proportional to the net force and {{d2}} proportional to its mass.

d2.tooltip: More mass for the same force means...?

sentences.text: The formula for Newton's Second Law is {{d3}}, which can be rearranged to find acceleration as {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Net force equals mass times what?

sentences.text: If the net force on a 4 kg object is 20 N, its acceleration is {{d5}}. If the mass doubles to 8 kg with the same force, the acceleration becomes {{d6}}.

d6.tooltip: Double mass means half the acceleration.

third_law.title: Newton's Third Law - Action and Reaction
third_law.instructions: Complete the statements about Newton's Third Law.

sentences.text: Newton's Third Law states that for every action force, there is an equal and {{d1}} reaction force. These two forces always act on {{d2}} objects.
When you push a wall with a force of 50 N, the wall pushes back on you with a force of {{d3}}. These forces do not cancel because they act on {{d4}}.

d4.tooltip: Forces only cancel when on the same object.

sentences.text: The correct way to identify the reaction to 'force on the book by the table' is {{d5}}. This reaction force is a {{d6}} force.

d5.correct: force on the table by the book
distractors: force on the book by gravity

d6.tooltip: Same type of force as the action.

two_dimensions.title: Forces in Two Dimensions
two_dimensions.instructions: Complete the statements about analyzing forces in two dimensions.

sentences.text: A free body diagram shows all {{d1}} acting on {{d2}} object, with arrows starting from the object and pointing in the direction of each force.

d2.tooltip: Isolate one object at a time.

sentences.text: To resolve a force F at angle θ from horizontal into components: the horizontal component is {{d3}} and the vertical component is {{d4}}.
For an object on an inclined plane at angle θ, the component of gravity parallel to the slope is {{d5}} and the component perpendicular to the slope is {{d6}}.

first_law.title: Applying the First Law
first_law.instructions: Apply Newton's First Law to practical scenarios.

sentences.text: A car cruising at constant 60 km/h on a straight, level road is in {{d1}} because its {{d2}} is zero, even though multiple forces act on it.

d2.tooltip: The vector sum of all forces.

sentences.text: A hockey puck sliding on frictionless ice continues at constant velocity because there is no {{d3}} to change its motion. This demonstrates the property of {{d4}}.

When a tablecloth is pulled quickly from under dishes, the dishes tend to stay in place due to their {{d5}}. This works because the force acts for too {{d6}} a time to significantly change their motion.

d5.tooltip: The dishes resist the change in motion.

second_law.title: Applying the Second Law
second_law.instructions: Apply Newton's Second Law to calculate forces and accelerations.

sentences.text: A 1500 kg car accelerates at 3 m/s². The net force on the car must be {{d1}}. If friction provides 500 N of resistance, the engine must provide a driving force of {{d2}}.

d2.tooltip: Driving force must overcome friction AND provide net force.

sentences.text: Two objects experience the same net force. Object A has twice the mass of object B. Object A's acceleration is {{d3}} that of object B because acceleration is {{d4}} proportional to mass.
A 0.5 kg ball experiences a gravitational force of approximately {{d5}}. If this is the only force, its acceleration is {{d6}} regardless of initial velocity.

third_law.title: Applying the Third Law
third_law.instructions: Apply Newton's Third Law to real-world scenarios.

sentences.text: When a person walks, they push {{d1}} on the ground. By Newton's Third Law, the ground pushes {{d2}} on the person, which is what actually accelerates them.

d1.tooltip: Your foot pushes which way on the ground?

sentences.text: A truck and a small car collide. The force on the car by the truck is {{d3}} the force on the truck by the car. However, the car experiences {{d4}} acceleration because it has less mass.

d4.tooltip: Same force, less mass → more acceleration.

sentences.text: A book sits on a table. The weight of the book acts {{d5}}. The reaction to the book's weight is {{d6}}, NOT the normal force from the table.

d5.tooltip: Weight is Earth pulling the book down.

two_dimensions.title: Two-Dimensional Force Analysis
two_dimensions.instructions: Apply force analysis to two-dimensional scenarios.

sentences.text: A 100 N force acts at 30° above horizontal. Its horizontal component is {{d1}} and its vertical component is {{d2}}.
A 2 kg box sits on a 30° inclined plane. The component of gravity pulling it down the slope is {{d3}} and the normal force equals {{d4}}.
For equilibrium in 2D, the net force must be zero in {{d5}} directions. This means ΣFx = 0 {{d6}} ΣFy = 0.

d5.tooltip: Equilibrium requires balance in all directions.

first_law.title: Mastering the First Law
first_law.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of Newton's First Law.

sentences.text: The common misconception that 'objects naturally come to rest' fails to account for {{d1}}, which creates a net force on moving objects in everyday situations.

d1.tooltip: What forces oppose motion in everyday life?

d2.tooltip: Zero net force means no change in velocity.

sentences.text: An astronaut in deep space, far from any gravitational fields, throws a ball. The ball will travel in a {{d2}} indefinitely because there are no {{d3}} to change its motion.

d2.tooltip: No forces means no change in velocity.

d3.tooltip: Forces are needed to change motion.

sentences.text: A heavier object has more inertia, meaning it requires {{d4}} to achieve the same acceleration. This explains why a loaded truck {{d5}} than an empty one when the same braking force is applied.

d4.tooltip: F = ma: more m needs more F for same a.

d5.tooltip: Same force, more mass → less deceleration.

second_law.title: Mastering the Second Law
second_law.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of Newton's Second Law.

sentences.text: The Second Law explains why all objects in free fall have the same acceleration: the gravitational force on an object is {{d1}}, so when substituted into a = F/m, the mass {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Weight = mg. What happens when you divide by m?

d2.tooltip: a = mg/m = g for all masses.

sentences.text: In a lift accelerating upward at 2 m/s², a 60 kg person experiences a net upward force of {{d3}}. Their apparent weight (normal force) is {{d4}}.

d4.tooltip: N - W = ma, so N = ma + mg

sentences.text: Two blocks connected by a string are pulled across a frictionless surface. The tension in the string is {{d5}} the applied force because the tension only needs to accelerate the {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: The applied force accelerates both blocks.

d6.tooltip: The front block is pulled by both applied force and tension.

third_law.title: Mastering the Third Law
third_law.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of Newton's Third Law.

sentences.text: A common error is thinking the normal force and weight are a Third Law pair. They are not because {{d1}} and they are {{d2}}.

d1.correct: they act on the same object
d1.tooltip: Third Law pairs must act on different objects.

d2.tooltip: Normal is contact; weight is gravitational.

sentences.text: Rockets work in space by expelling gas {{d3}}. The reaction force of the gas on the rocket pushes it {{d4}}, demonstrating that Third Law pairs don't require a medium.

d3.tooltip: The rocket pushes gas one way...

d4.tooltip: ...and the gas pushes the rocket the opposite way.

sentences.text: When a horse pulls a cart, the horse and cart accelerate despite equal and opposite forces between them because the Third Law pair acts on {{d5}}. The horse accelerates because the ground's friction on the horse is {{d6}} the cart's pull on the horse.

d5.tooltip: One force on horse, one on cart.

d6.tooltip: Net force on horse must be forward for forward acceleration.

two_dimensions.title: Mastering Two-Dimensional Analysis
two_dimensions.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of force analysis in two dimensions.

sentences.text: A box is pulled along a surface by a rope at angle θ above horizontal. Increasing θ {{d1}} the horizontal component and {{d2}} the normal force from the surface.

d1.tooltip: Fx = F cos θ. Larger θ means smaller cos θ.

d2.tooltip: The vertical component partially supports the box.

sentences.text: On a frictionless incline, the only force component along the slope is {{d3}}, giving an acceleration of {{d4}} regardless of the object's mass.

d4.tooltip: a = F/m = mg sin θ / m

sentences.text: Three coplanar forces of 30 N, 40 N, and 50 N can produce equilibrium if arranged to form a {{d5}}. This is possible because {{d6}}.

d6.tooltip: Equilibrium means Fnet = 0 in all directions.
